hints.content:
Jane works at a rate of $\$\blueD5$ for every $\greenD1$ dog.

The values in the table represent ratios that are equivalent to this rate.

If Jane walks $3$ times as many dogs, she earns $3$ times as much money.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/510df02c700a24955cec96f5ff64f93938dd88b8)

If Jane walks $5$ times as many dogs, she earns $5$ times as much money.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/61e25614b8f17b9882793592e975945728fac687)

Now we can graph each ratio as an ordered pair in the form $(x,y)$.   

Dogs, $x$ | Charge in dollars, $y$ | Ordered pair $(x,y)$
:-: | :-: | :-:
$1$ |  $5$ | $(1,5)$
$3$|  $15$ | $(3,15)$
$5$ |  $25$ | $(5,25)$



![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1171bf49085e97bec0511645cfde6c8fac22be64)

The completed table

Dogs, $x$ | Charge in dollars, $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ |  $5$
$3$|  $15$
$5$ |  $25$

And the completed graph

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1171bf49085e97bec0511645cfde6c8fac22be64)

question.content:
Jane earns money walking dogs on the weekends. Jane charges $\$5$ for each dog she walks.

**Complete the table for the given ratio.** 
  
Dogs, $x$ | Charge in dollars, $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ |  $5$
$3$| [[☃ numeric-input 3]]
$5$ |  [[☃ numeric-input 5]]

**Plot the ordered pairs $(x,y)$ from the table on the following graph.** 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Callan hikes at a rate of $\blueD3$ miles for every $\greenD1$ hour.

The values in the table represent ratios that are equivalent to this rate.

If Callan hikes $3$ times as many hours, he hikes $3$ times as many miles.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b549afce89cfdace9feb34f02c1f49cb18250c41)

If Callan hikes $5$ times as many hours, he hikes $5$ times as many miles.

Now we can graph each ratio as an ordered pair in the form $(x,y)$.   

Hours, $x$ | Miles, $y$ | Ordered pair $(x,y)$
:-: | :-: | :-:
$1$ |  $3$ | $(1,3)$
$3$|  $9$ | $(3,9)$
$5$ |  $15$ | $(5,15)$



![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/843c416e39e35bc9edf97722da4019467beb433f)

The completed table

Hours, $x$ | Miles, $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ |  $3$
$3$| $9$
$5$ |  $15$


And the completed graph

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/843c416e39e35bc9edf97722da4019467beb433f)

Campers, $x$ | Counselors, $y$ 
:-: | :-:

$30$| [[☃ numeric-input 3]]
$45$ |  [[☃ numeric-input 5]]

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueD{\text{number of cars Drew washes}}$ to the $\goldD{\text{amount of money Drew charges}}$.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueD2,\goldD{15})$ represents the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{15}$ and means that for every $\blueD2$ cars Drew washes he charges $\$\goldD{15}$.

To find out how much Drew earns for washing $4$ cars, we can multiply both numbers in the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{15}$ by $2$.

If Drew washes $2$ times as many cars, he earns $2$ times as much money.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8a230f566bb59a92483a1a99d03fe97725173114)

We can plot the ratio $(4,30)$ on the coordinate plane to see if it is line with the other ratios. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5b240ba20ad77b48085bff9a4da70abda64604db)
Drew charges $\$30$ for washing $4$ cars.

question.content:
Drew earns money washing cars for his neighbors on the weekends. Drew charges a set rate for each car he washes.

The points on the following coordinate plane show how much Drew charges for $2$, $5$, and $8$ cars. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/edf79550ea717eeba5a44fa42170197fa85264c6)


**How much does Drew charge for $4$ cars?** 

$\$$ [[☃ numeric-input 12]]

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueD{\text{number of servings}}$ to the $\goldD{\text{number of gummi bears}}$.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueD2,\goldD{40})$ represents the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{40}$ and means that for every $\blueD2$ servings, there are $\goldD{40}$ gummi bears.

To find out how many gummi bears there are in $4$ servings, we can multiply both numbers in the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{40}$ by $2$.

If there are $2$ times as many servings, there are also  $2$ times as many gummi bears.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/280757e2559a760dd4b1bf4b5eed3f16745768cf)

We can plot the ratio $(4, 80)$ on the coordinate plane to see if it is line with the other ratios. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/51a49abadb91e6df0bbc2da1ccff4c2954e3c5df)
There are  $80$ gummi bears in $4$ servings.

question.content:
Federico read the nutritional information on a package of  gummi bears.

The points on the following coordinate plane show how many gummi bears there are  in $2$, $3$, and $5$ servings. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ee8fa2443c9e2d4f0d74338702e01f87204bd4a5)


**How many gummi bears are there in $4$ servings?** 

 [[☃ numeric-input 12]] gummi bears

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueD{\text{number of seconds on the zip line}}$ to the $\goldD{\text{number of feet Richard traveled}}$.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueD2,\goldD{80})$ represents the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{80}$ and means that for every $\blueD2$ seconds, Richard travels  $\goldD{80}$ feet.

To find out how far Richard travels in $1$ second, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{80}$ by $2$.

If we divide the number of seconds traveled by $2$, we also need to divide the number of feet traveled by $2$.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/af33496835f7f5570cbb5d120ecb1fb309d2e9eb)

We can plot the ratio $(1, 40)$ on the coordinate plane to see if it is line with the other ratios. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9fb37881d5d01a6293416f9b227d2c59590bcc48)
Richard travels $40$ feet in $1$ second on the zip line.

question.content:
Richard went to a zip line park for his birthday.  Richard travels on the zip line at a constant rate.

The points on the following coordinate plane show how many feet he travelled in $2$, $3$, and $4$ seconds while riding one of the zip lines. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/439400a2409e558f14d009cdfad5ba728117e997)


**How far does Richard travel on the zip line in $1$ second?** 

 [[☃ numeric-input 12]] feet

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueD{\text{number of layers}}$ to the $\goldD{\text{number of bricks}}$.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueD2,\goldD{100})$ represents the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{100}$ and means that for every $\blueD2$ layers there are   $\goldD{100}$ bricks.

To find out how many bricks are used in $1$ layer, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{100}$ by $2$.

If  we divide the number of layers by $2$, we also need to divide the number of bricks by $2$. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/957ef5d445bcb2303d91e72a7fa54163117156c2)

We can plot the ratio $(1, 50)$ on the coordinate plane to see if it is line with the other ratios. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e0f5338ef163e8e4bc115d01ef4e95e6961c9be6)
There are  $50$ bricks in $1$ layer of the wall.

question.content:
A bricklayer is building a wall.  Each layer of the wall has the same number of bricks.

The points on the following coordinate plane show how many bricks he used to make $2$, $3$, and $4$ layers of the wall. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ba8366a00bf6dd6991072c0312ed131e37b49a64)


**How many bricks are used in $1$ layer of the wall?** 

 [[☃ numeric-input 12]] bricks

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueD{\text{number of lifeguards}}$ to the $\goldD{\text{number of swimmers}}$.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueD2,\goldD{70})$ represents the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{70}$ and means that for every $\blueD2$ lifeguards there can be $\goldD{70}$ swimmers.

To find out how many swimmers can be in the pool for $1$ lifeguard, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{70}$ by $2$.

If we divide the number of lifeguards by $2$ we should also divide  the number of swimmers by $2$. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/92039b347d3408ff42861d247d07f1dc7323f608)

Now that we know the number of swimmers for $1$ lifeguard, we can multiply both parts of the ratio by $3$ to find the number of swimmers for $3$ lifeguards.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/dfc2565ab5323a0c714e67ab033749a6c4329968)

We can plot the ratio $(3, 105)$ on the coordinate plane to see if it is line with the other ratios. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/851a34d2d1582419c446dfff83ac581b4d1a4fca)
There can be $105$ swimmers in the pool with  $3$ lifeguards.

question.content:
A swimming pool sets a maximum number of swimmers that can be in the pool based on the number of lifeguards on duty.

The points on the following coordinate plane show the maximum number of swimmers that can be in the pool when $2$, $4$, and $5$ lifeguards are on duty.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3bf626b70f9e1234f4f5765181a9a1ee0e11c67a)


**What is the maximum number of swimmers that can be in the pool with $3$ lifeguards on duty?** 

 [[☃ numeric-input 12]] swimmers

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueD{\text{number of times }}$ McKenna shovels to the $\goldD{\text{number of dollars}}$ McKenna earns.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueD3,\goldD{18})$ represents the ratio $\blueD3:\goldD{18}$ and means that every $\blueD3$ times McKenna shovels, she earns $\$\goldD{18}$.

To find out how much McKenna earns for shoveling $1$ time, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueD3:\goldD{18}$ by $3$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d3e529093410119d85683ba5f1fa8a6724e45890)

McKenna earns $\$6$ each time she shovels.

We can use this rate to see which ordered pair McKenna can add to her graph.

## Ordered pair $(1,10)$:


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f4adccadabe8f53d988794ff246e7b52760ca48e)

The ratio of $1:10$ is **not** an equivalent ratio.

## Ordered pair $(2, 12)$:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f23f8a10394eb8057fdd6802b9dff4bacc3cdbd3)

Yes, the ratio of $2:12$ is  an equivalent ratio!

## Ordered pair $(6,34)$:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ea04978cd311fab017fdd8410018c520c27fafc0)

The ratio of $6:34$ is **not** an equivalent ratio.

When we plot all three sets of coordinate pairs, we can see that the ratio $(2, 12)$ is in line with the other ratios. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a70de9e4bf228a3d9954c72609a45edfd33b9822)
McKenna could add the ordered pair $(2, 12)$ to the graph.

question.content:
McKenna earns money each time she shovels snow for her neighbors. 

McKenna plots points on the coordinate plane below to show how much she earns for different numbers of times she shovels snow.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c0032b5946b96d736232a9dc92d477c94c652f9a)

**Which of the following ordered pairs could McKenna add to the graph?** 

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueD{\text{number of hours}}$ Maggie walks to the $\goldD{\text{number of miles}}$ Maggie walks.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueD2,\goldD{7})$ represents the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{7}$ and means that every $\blueD2$ hours, Maggie can walk $\goldD{7}$ miles.

To find out how far Maggie walks in $1$ hour, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{7}$ by $2$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5f89a60f5a2b9662e1a211804d3e4d72a8077ef3)

Maggie walks $3.5$ miles per hour.

We can use this rate to see which ordered pair Maggie can add to her graph.

## Ordered pair $(1,3)$:


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e62ac4ab3b929e79dcade7c88c58581b3ba5fd9e)

The ratio of $1:3$ is **not** an equivalent ratio.

## Ordered pair $(3, 10)$:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/72f130d5a307ff052d3ed98c3661a3475f695efd)

The ratio of $3:10$ is **not** an equivalent ratio.

## Ordered pair $(6,21)$:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7890134b8f906d56bc059b800ed0b38b6200bc97)

Yes, the ratio of $6:21$ is an equivalent ratio!

When we plot all three sets of coordinate pairs, we can see that the ratio $(6, 21)$ is in line with the other ratios. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/dec598d2278a6e3a55992ddfa14c2b169f770888)
Maggie could add the ordered pair $(6, 21)$ to the graph.

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueD{\text{number of batches of salsa}}$  to the $\goldD{\text{number of tomatoes}}$ needed.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueD2,\goldD{6})$ represents the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{6}$ and means that every $\blueD2$ batches of salsa, Lucas will need $\goldD{6}$ tomatoes.

To find out how many tomatoes Lucas needs for $1$ batch of salsa, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueD2:\goldD{6}$ by $2$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e0f954b24aec9ce936d80242eed891d0ee6d1b90)

Lucas needs $3$ tomatoes for each batch of salsa.

We can use this rate to see which ordered pair Lucas can add to his graph.

## Ordered pair $(3, 1)$:


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ed76a4003314554274e052738ea15a0d44f726ab)

The ratio of $3:1$ is **not** an equivalent ratio.

## Ordered pair $(4, 12)$:


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5d5deceb11052e6e5481025b36d53c7cdae8dd7f)

Yes, the ratio of $4:12$ is an equivalent ratio!

## Ordered pair $(6, 16)$:


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c979a187695d61fef684bca8c40dbb0ac1a7fe72)

The ratio of $6:16$ is **not** an equivalent ratio.

When we plot all three sets of coordinate pairs, we can see that the ratio $(4, 12)$ is in line with the other ratios. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4a2264444e101c5b468918b3a333fd898cff960a)
Lucas could add the ordered pair $(4, 12)$ to the graph.

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueD{\text{number of cups of water}}$   to the $\goldD{\text{number of cups of salt}}$.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueD6,\goldD{3})$ represents the ratio $\blueD6:\goldD{3}$ and means that every $\blueD6$ cups of water, Briggs will need $\goldD{3}$ cups of salt.

To find out how many cups of salt Briggs will need for  $1$ cup of water, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueD6:\goldD{3}$ by $6$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/052c5d0c997b241ee1dd33d26bbb41f4d57bd4db)

Briggs will need $0.5$ cups of salt for each cup of water.

We can use this rate to see which ordered pair Briggs can add to his graph.

## Ordered pair $(1, 1)$:


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d595747fead5c4ddec6d2c950556d13e27281c4d)

The ratio of $1:1$ is **not** an equivalent ratio.

## Ordered pair $(3.5, 7)$:


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a557da7d2b58740e144097ce67a8fc3d3bb65983)

The ratio of $3.5:7$ is **not** an equivalent ratio.

## Ordered pair $(9, 4.5)$:


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5c35130c35790d226bfe3e485003de36c5139be9)

Yes, the ratio of $9:4.5$ is  an equivalent ratio!

When we plot all three sets of coordinate pairs, we can see that the ratio $(9, 4.5)$ is in line with the other ratios. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/39bbb3749af91dfe3c6387f094992b05280a7aa6)
Briggs could add the ordered pair $(9, 4.5)$ to the graph.

question.content:
Briggs is planning to make a batch of homemade play dough for an art project.

Briggs plots points on the coordinate plane below to show the amount of salt he needs for different amounts of water.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/045ab39274cc3e1b32ce005378805f236f811f96)

**Which of the following ordered pairs could Briggs add to the graph?** 


[[☃ radio 2]]
